options: Stay one second behind the vehicle in front of you.
Drive as close to the vehicle in front as possible.
Stay at least three seconds behind the vehicle in front of you.
questions.qn: Under good conditions, when driving behind any vehicle, at any speed, you should -

options: Take longer and further to stop, so slow down.
Stop in the same distance as on a dry road.
Handle better, so you can go faster.
questions.qn: When driving in wet weather, your vehicle will -

options: Close your eyes for a short time until they recover.
Watch the centre line of the road.
Slow down, until your eyes recover.
questions.qn: At night, if an oncoming vehicle's headlights dazzle you, you should -

options: Turn on the air conditioning or open the windows.
Stop, rest, and change drivers if possible.
Turn on the radio very loud.
questions.qn: If you get sleepy while driving, it is best to -

options: Flash your headlights to warn other drivers.
Turn your headlights on high beam.
Turn on your headlights, slow down, and double your following distance behind the vehicle in front.
questions.qn: In wet weather when it becomes hard for you to see, you should -

options: Put your hazard warning lights on and increase your speed to avoid the rain.
Put your lights on high beam so you can see better.
Slow down using the brake gently, since rain and oil may create a slippery surface.
questions.qn: If you are driving and it starts to rain, you should -

options: Be easier to steer and handle
Take longer and further to stop.
Be heavier to steer.
questions.qn: When driving on a slippery wet road, for example, one covered in early morning dew, your vehicle will -

options: Your wheels may skid and cause a loss of control.
If the wheels lock up your handbrake may not work.
You might wet pedestrians walking along the footpath.
questions.qn: Why should you avoid heavy braking on a wet road?

options: Drive closer to the vehicle in front so they can see you better.
Use your hazard warning lights when overtaking another vehicle.
Leave a longer gap behind the vehicle in front.
questions.qn: At night you should -

options: Follow closer to other vehicles.
Slow down and use your low beam headlights and hazard warning lights to make your vehicle seen.
Put on your high beam lights.
questions.qn: When it is very foggy during the day or night and your vehicle has no fog lights, you should -

options: Get plenty of rest before starting out.
Make sure your horn is working.
Have a good meal before driving.
questions.qn: When going on a long trip, out of the following which is the most important to do?

options: Not look at its headlights, but keep left and watch the left of the road.
Carefully watch the vehicle by looking directly at its headlights.
Put your lights on high beam, to make your vehicle more easily seen.
questions.qn: At night, when you approach an oncoming vehicle, you should -

options: Crashing or not crashing is a matter of luck
It is up to other drivers to avoid crashing into me.
When I drive, I have the main responsibility for my safety and the safety of other road users.
questions.qn: Which of the following attitudes is most likely to make you a safer driver?

options: Adjust your seat.
Check over your shoulder.
Put on your seat belt.
questions.qn: You are about to move away from the kerb in your car. What is the last thing you should do before you move into traffic?

options: Check your mirrors and look over your shoulder before moving off from the kerb.
Have a good look around while you walk up to your car and then drive off as soon as you can.
Sound your horn before moving away from the kerb to warn people of your intentions
questions.qn: What is the best way to avoid hitting other vehicles, people or animals when moving off from the kerb?

options: Drive in every kind of traffic situation as soon as you get your licence.
Drive as much as you can with friends on the way to parties.
Start driving in daylight where it is not too busy and only drive in busier traffic as your driving gets better.
questions.qn: Many people crash within the first few years of driving. What is the best way of learning to drive on your own without crashing?

options: Looking in the rear and side mirrors continually when driving.
Continually looking ahead, to the sides and using all mirrors when driving.
Looking further ahead down the road when driving.
questions.qn: It is important to scan while driving so you can see everything that is happening on the road. What does scanning involve?

options: Drive mainly in unfamiliar streets.
Drive long distances to improve your concentration
Drive mainly on streets that you know well.
questions.qn: If you are a new driver and first start to drive at night you should -

options: Pull off the road, stop and rest until you no longer feel tired.
Stop at a shop and get a drink that contains caffeine to help keep you awake.
Make sure you get plenty of fresh air circulating inside the car by winding down your window.
questions.qn: You set out on a fairly long drive to see some friends. After a while you start feeling tired. What should you do?

options: Drop them off at the train station.
Take the advice of a more experience driver and go faster where you can.
Choose a safe speed and say you will not go any faster.
questions.qn: You are driving an older relative for an appointment and are running late. They ask you to go faster to get there on time. You should -

options: Aim to drive for as long as possible when you are feeling good so you can arrive earlier.
Drive mostly at night as there is less traffic on the road and therefore less risk of crashing.
Drive during the day, take plenty of breaks and share driving if possible.
questions.qn: You are planning to drive from Sydney to the Gold Coast with some friends. To minimise fatigue and make the trip as safe as possible you should -

options: 3 seconds.
1 seconds.
2 seconds.
questions.qn: You should leave a gap between your vehicle and the one you are following. In good conditions the gap should be -

options: The same 3-second gap you would leave during the day.
A gap of about 2 seconds so you can watch the vehicles in front closely and see when they are stopping.
A gap of about 4 seconds as it is easy to misjudge distances at night.
questions.qn: It is night time and you are driving home from the movies. You are travelling in a line of vehicles. What size gap should you leave between your vehicle and the vehicles in front of you?

options: Chase the car to tell the driver how to drive.
Stay calm and in control of your vehicle at all times.
Respond by using your horn and/or flashing your lights to let the driver know how you feel.
questions.qn: While driving, you come across aggressive, selfish or ignorant driving behaviour by another driver. You should -

options: Check your mirrors and look over your shoulder before moving off from the kerb.
Have a good look around while you walk up to your car and then drive off as soon as you can.
Sound your horn before moving away from the kerb to warn people of your intentions
